subject: Re: [d@DCC] MS censors UN document
body:
Hi Scott,

I am by no means defending MS who clearly over-reached in this instance
but the document in question wasn't to my knowledge published by the UN
and at most would have had a UN logo somewhere alongside a bunch of other
logos from other financial sponsors...

So my guess is that the document has more or less disappeared.  The recent
de facto endorsement of open source by the UNDP (in fact I believe it was
by something called APDIP which is sponsored by the UNDP) is a far more
important and long lasting development with practical results on the
ground especially in Asia.

There has been a lot of other to-ing and fro-ing around MS and OS in
various UN post-WSIS venues but the story is too long and tangled and my
memory too selective to follow it... Do some searching on WSIS and IGF
(Internet Governance Forum) and MS and see what turns up.

Good luck with it,

MG

> On 5/29/07, mgurst@vcn.bc.ca  wrote:
>> One final note, to call the proceedings a "UN document" is a gross
>> distortion... The conference was not I believe an "official" UN
>> conference
>> but may have been "endorsed" by one or another UN agency--it happens
>> fairly often; and the proceedings were the proceedings of a mostly
>> Austrian funded and sponsored conference that mattered very little in
>> the
>> great scheme of things and wasn't so far as I know of much significance
>> even in the context of WSIS.
>
> Thanks for your thoughts MG.  Again, more recent references would be
> wonderful, but going on what you've provided thus far...
>
> I understand that happens, (too often for my personal liking) but does
> not the fact that a document "endorsed" by a UN agency (regardless of
> the sponsorship of any individual or group of nations), regarding a
> related conference, make said document - in it's final form - an
> "official" UN document?
>
> Perhaps it was sponsored by Austria, but if it is a UN document why
> then should MS have _any_ control over the contents of the document?
>
> There are many areas in which I could use schooling - politics first
> among them.  =)
>
> Thanks again.
> - Scott.
>
